channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Defying Arrest Deadline, Brazil’s Ex-President Dares Police to Come Get Him
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil outside the headquarters of the metal workers’ union in São Bernardo do Campo on Friday. The former leader spent Thursday night there as he weighed his response to an arrest warrant.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: The decision by former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva raised the specter of a dramatic showdown with law enforcement officials.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON, ERNESTO LONDOÑO and MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: Oprah, Rupert Murdoch, Harvard: Saudi Prince’s U.S. Tour
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, right, with the Google co-founder Sergey Brin on Friday at Google headquarters in Mountain View, Calif.
item.description: The Saudi heir to the throne has been on an extraordinary tour of the United States, seeking investment and trying to change perceptions of the opaque, conservative kingdom.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 10 Killed in Gaza as Palestinian Protesters Face Off With Israeli Soldiers
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters flocked to the Israel-Gaza border on Friday. The protests are aimed at Israel’s blockade, which began after Hamas seized control of Gaza in 2007.
item.description: Though the protest and casualties were smaller than those last week, they made a point: portraying Gaza as a prison with Israel as the jailer.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER, IYAD ABUHEWEILA and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Trump Administration Imposes New Sanctions on Putin Cronies
item.media:description: New United States sanctions are designed to penalize President Vladimir V. Putin while sparing wider Russian society.
item.description: The Trump administration, carrying out sanctions pressed by Congress for election interference, announced new penalties against Russia’s richest men.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Meet the 7 Russian Oligarchs Hit by the New U.S. Sanctions
item.media:description: Vladimir L. Bogdanov is director general and a co-owner of Surgutneftegas, a Russian oil company.
item.description: The list includes some of the world’s richest people, from multiple industries, with fortunes that are closely tied to their relations with the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS, OLEG MATSNEV and IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Park Geun-hye, South Korea’s Ousted President, Gets 24 Years in Prison
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Park Geun-hye of South Korea calling for her release on Friday, near the courthouse in Seoul where she was sentenced.
item.description: The corruption scandal that ended Ms. Park’s presidency exposed the collusive ties between South Korea’s government and conglomerates like Samsung.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: He Says He’s an Innocent Victim. Robert Mueller Says He’s a Spy.
item.media:description: Konstantin V. Kilimnik once worked for Paul Manafort’s political consulting and advising operation out of this storefront in Kiev, Ukraine. As befits a man labeled a Russian spy by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, there are no photographs extant of Mr. Kilimnik.
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.description: Konstantin V. Kilimnik, a 47-year-old former Russian military interpreter, is nicknamed “the midget.” But he’s looming large in the special counsel’s inquiry.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP

item.title: Top Pakistani News Channel Is Forced Off Air, and Eyes Are on the Military
item.media:description: Geo News, Pakistan’s most widely watched network, says it has been forced off the air over 80 percent of the country.
item.description: Civilian regulators insist there’s no block. But Geo News finds itself widely shut down after critical reporting on the army’s flexing of its authority.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Lower-Caste Fury Shakes India, and Hints at Fiery Election Ahead
item.media:description: A Dalit man was surrounded and struck by police officers on Monday in Ahmadabad, India, during a nationwide strike.
item.description: Just a generation ago, people would move out of the way to avoid touching a Dalit. Now, a huge demonstration shows they have become a potential force.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: China, Russia, Cardi B: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Sexual Misconduct Claim Spurs Nobel Members to Step Aside in Protest
item.media:description: Peter Englund in 2014. Mr. Englund was one of three members to withdraw from the Swedish Academy on Friday.
item.description: Three members of the Swedish Academy, which selects the winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, have withdrawn over the handling of misconduct allegations involving a member’s spouse.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Hanged After a Trial He Couldn’t Understand, and Pardoned 136 Years Later
item.media:description: A rendering of the court during the trials of three men accused of murder in Maamtrasna, Ireland, in 1882. One of the accused, Myles Joyce, was pardoned this week.
item.media:credit: Universal History Archive, via Getty Images
item.description: The trial in Dublin that convicted Myles Joyce, who spoke only Irish, was conducted in English. He protested his innocence until the moment he was executed.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Why A.I. First Spoke With a Canadian Accent: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: HAL 9000, the fictional computer that set the standard for how virtual assistants like Siri and Alexa sound today.
item.description: A filmmaker reveals how an actor from Winnipeg was the voice of HAL 9000. Also in this week’s newsletter: readers’ thoughts about Facebook.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Unknown or Unreal? The Shadow on Some Russian Avant-Garde Art
item.media:description: The painting “Black Rectangle, Red Square,” in a German public collection, was once thought to have been painted in 1915 by Kazimir Malevich, but last year was found to be a forgery.
item.description: In a spate of recent incidents, experts have questioned the authenticity of works said to have been painted by the Russian masters of the period.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE HICKLEY

item.title: U.S. and China Play Chicken on Trade, and Neither Swerves
item.media:description: China wants to create a commercial aircraft maker to rival Boeing or Airbus.
item.description: Victory could be difficult to verify, much less achieve, as the U.S. protests Beijing’s effort to retool Chinese industries for the 21st century.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Trump Aims New Threat at China as Mnuchin Warns of Trade War
item.media:description: Workers at an aluminum plant in Huaibei, China last year. The price of aluminum per pound has been falling since February, a decline that started before the tariffs were imposed.
item.media:credit: STR, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.description: President Trump launched into a new defense of his pugnacious trade policies on Friday, pointing to the falling price of aluminum to deny harm to consumers.
item.dc:creator: ANA SWANSON and EILEEN SULLIVAN

item.title: Skripal Cousin Says She Doesn’t Trust Britain on Chemical Attack
item.media:description: Police officers stand guard outside the home of former Russian military intelligence officer Sergei Skripal in Salisbury, Britain, last month.
item.description: Sergei Skripal’s condition has improved from critical to stable. Russian officials want access to his daughter, but Britain says she hasn’t yet accepted it.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

item.title: Jacob Zuma Appears in Court for South Africa Corruption Trial
item.media:description: Former President Jacob Zuma appeared in court in Durban, South Africa, on Friday. He faces charges including corruption and fraud.
item.description: The brevity of his appearance did not detract from the powerful image of Mr. Zuma, a commanding figure just a few months ago, as a defendant.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Escort Who Claims to Have Russian Secrets Faces New Charges in Thailand
item.media:description: Anastasia Vashukevich, left, and her associate Alexander Kirillov, far right, after their arrest in Pattaya, Thailand, in February.
item.description: Anastasia Vashukevich is still in Thai custody, hoping to trade what she says is evidence that Russia meddled in the American presidential election.
item.dc:creator: RYN JIRENUWAT and RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Malaysian Leader Jump-Starts Elections, and Stacks the Odds
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad during a rally in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, last month. The elections will pit current Prime Minister Najib Razak against his erstwhile mentor, Mr. Mahathir.
item.description: “It’s like a civil war in Malaysia right now,” one opposition figure said as Prime Minister Najib Razak muzzles the press and dissent ahead of the vote.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH

item.title: Bright Lights, Big Shoulder Pads: A Timid Japan Recalls Its Bubble Era
item.media:description: Kaori Masukodera, left, and Mai Chusonji of the duo Bed In, whose garish outfits and bubbly music are part of a nostalgic reappreciation of Japan’s 1980s economic boom.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The country’s mild new prosperity has rekindled an interest in the 1980s, when the Japanese economy truly boomed and a sense of ascendance fueled spenders.
item.dc:creator: MARI SAITO

item.title: Too Radical for France, a Muslim Clergyman Faces Deportation
item.media:description: El Hadi Doudi, an imam who preaches a fundamentalist form of Islam, at a courthouse in Marseille, France, in February. The French government is trying to expel him.
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, who has taken advantage of his office’s powers, appears poised to expel El Hadi Doudi, making clear he won’t tolerate radical preachers.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Judge Orders Brazil’s Ex-President ‘Lula’ to Begin Prison Term on Friday
item.media:description: The former president of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, will start serving a 12-year prison sentence for corruption on Friday.
item.description: The party of former President Luiz Inácio Lula remained defiant, saying he will still run in the coming presidential election.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Israel and Gaza Brace for Round 2 of Protests at Border Fence
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters burned tires near the Israel-Gaza border on Thursday.
item.description: Israel defended the lethal tactics used last week. Hamas said demonstrators would be unarmed at Friday’s protest, but prepared piles of tires to burn.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and IYAD ABUHEWEILA

item.title: Iraq, Trump, Pruitt: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Turkish Secret Agents Seized 80 People in 18 Countries, Official Says
item.media:description: Supporters of Turkey’s president waved Turkish flags last year during the first anniversary of a failed coup in 2016.
item.description: The assertion by a Turkish government official suggested clandestine arrests like the C.I.A. renditions after the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: As Migrant Caravan Splinters, Trump Takes Credit and Mexico Scoffs
item.media:description: Migrants gathering for breakfast Thursday at a sports complex in Matías Romero, Mexico. A local church provided the meal.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: The caravan, largely consisting of desperate Central Americans, is dispersing but plans to regroup elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Russian Historian Who Exposed Soviet Crimes Is Cleared in Pornography Case
item.media:description: The historian Yuri A. Dmitriev spoke to reporters after being cleared of child pornography charges on Thursday.
item.description: A court acquitted Yuri A. Dmitriev, who discovered a mass grave with 9,000 bodies, of what he had called politically motivated charges.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Groups in Myanmar Fire Back at Zuckerberg
item.media:description: A half-dozen civil society groups in Myanmar said in an open letter on Thursday that Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, had mischaracterized the social network’s efforts to detect hate speech in their country.
item.description: Responding to Mark Zuckerberg’s comments in a Vox interview, civil society advocates said Facebook had no consistent methods for dealing with hate speech in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Puigdemont Cannot Be Extradited on Rebellion Charge, German Court Rules
item.media:description: A protest in Barcelona last month in support of Catalonian politicians jailed on charges of sedition and condemning the arrest in Germany of the former Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont.
item.description: The former Catalan leader is freed on bail, while a court decides whether he can be extradited to Spain on a lesser charge.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Yulia Skripal Is Awake and at the Center of a Russia-U. K. Confrontation
item.media:description: A picture of Yulia Skripal obtained from her Facebook account. A month after being poisoned by a rare nerve agent, she is awake and talking.
item.description: Two accounts of her health illustrate the challenge Britain faces in maintaining a global coalition around the poisoning while keeping much of its evidence secret.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: At War: U.S. Forces in Syria: Building More Outposts, Pulling Up Lawn Chairs
item.media:description: A United States position, installed near the front line between the U.S-backed Syrian Manbij Military Council and the Turkish-backed fighters, in Manbij, north Syria, Wednesday, April 4.
item.description: While Washington figures out its stance on Syria, American forces on the ground are building up their front-line positions.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Why China Is Confident It Can Beat Trump in a Trade War
item.media:description: Imported soybeans at a port in Nantong, China. The latest Chinese tariffs were intended to deliver a warning that American producers and consumers would pay in a trade war.
item.description: Beijing has a strong grip on banks, the news media and politics, and it seems willing to take advantage of vulnerabilities in the American political system.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Volokolamsk journal: ‘When a City of 40,000 People Gets Poisoned, They Don’t Care’
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Yadrovo landfill site near the town of Volokolamsk, west of Moscow.
item.description: The 1,000 or so truckloads of waste produced daily in Moscow had to go somewhere. After other dumps were overwhelmed, one 75 miles away is dealing with the waste.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: China Bans Online Bible Sales as It Tightens Religious Controls
item.media:description: Worshipers reading from the Bible at a underground church in Tianjin, China. The Bible is printed in China but legally available only at certain bookstores.
item.description: The move aligns with a longstanding effort to limit the influence of Christianity in the country.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Queen Sofía and Queen Letizia Face Off, and Spain Is Aghast
item.media:description: Queen Letizia, right, with her daughters, Princess Sofía and Princess Leonor, and the girls’ grandmother Queen Sofía at Palma Cathedral in Mallorca on Easter Sunday.
item.description: Footage spread quickly on social media of what appeared to be a public royal spat on Easter Sunday.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Solar Power Is Burning Bright. But It’s Hardly Twilight for Fossil Fuels.
item.media:description: New panels in India. Solar power accounted for more than a third of all electricity from energy sources that came online in 2017.
item.description: The world added more solar power than any other energy source in 2017. But it's still a tiny fraction of total electricity.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Salman Khan, Bollywood Superstar, Is Convicted of Killing Antelopes
item.media:description: The Bollywood star Salman Khan, center, before appearing in court in Jodhpur, in Rajasthan State, on Thursday. He was sentenced to five years in prison; his lawyers said they would appeal, and apply for bail.
item.description: The actor was sentenced to five years in prison in a case that has extended over nearly two decades. His lawyers said they would appeal, and apply for bail.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Women Barred From Sumo Ring, Even to Save a Man’s Life
item.media:description: The Tokyo Grand Sumo tournament in 2015. Today’s tradition of barring women from the ring is as much a habit as anything else, said Lee Thompson, a professor of sports science at Waseda University.
item.description: The ejection of women trying to help a politician who had collapsed was seen as a metaphor for how poorly women are regarded in Japan.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: India Is Close to Buying a Russian Missile System, Despite U.S. Sanctions
item.media:description: India is on the verge of buying five Russian-made S-400 Triumf surface-to-air missile systems like these.
item.description: The potential $6 billion purchase of Russia’s S-400 missile defense system comes as the United States is trying to cultivate military ties with India.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Pentagon Wades Deeper Into Detainee Operations in Syria
item.media:description: A Bahraini man suspected of aiding ISIS was detained by Kurdish forces in Syria in February. Several thousand detainees are being held in camps in northern Syria, American and Kurdish officials said.
item.description: The United States military is spending about $1 million to secure several makeshift detention camps for Islamic State prisoners, broadening its involvement in operations it had sought to avoid.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Letter 52: Gender Progress in Macho Australia?
item.media:description: The bookseller Lam Wing-kee in Hong Kong.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: The director of The New York Times Gender Initiative shares her impressions and questions after a busy visit to Sydney and Melbourne.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: In Sparing Consumers Tariff Burden, Trump Hit Manufacturing
item.media:description: A Boeing 737 on the assembly line in Renton, Wash. Aircraft and their parts are the single largest American export to China, making Boeing a tempting target in a trade war.
item.description: If the tariffs stand, along with China’s retaliatory moves, they could damage industries that have relied on a global supply chain for their recovery.
item.dc:creator: NATALIE KITROEFF and BEN CASSELMAN

item.title: Inside an Immigrant Caravan: Women and Children, Fleeing Violence
item.media:description: Central American migrants, members of a group making its way through Mexico, waited in line on Wednesday to review their visa status at a temporary camp in Matías Romero.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: The Central American migrants traveling through Mexico and singled out by President Trump as a threat are mostly women and children whose lives were in danger back home.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Sierra Leone’s Opposition Leader Is Sworn In as President
item.media:description: The opposition presidential candidate in Sierra Leone, Julius Maada Bio, was sworn in as president on Wednesday after a second round of voting.
item.description: The new president, Julius Maada Bio, won a runoff after a campaign in which he promised to provide free education and rejuvenate the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: U.S. Seeks 20-Year Prison Term for Turkish Banker in Sanctions Case
item.media:description: The deputy general manager for international banking at the Turkish state bank Halkbank was convicted in January at a trial that depicted high-level corruption in Turkey.
item.description: A Turkish banker convicted in New York of conspiring to evade the Iran sanctions deserves a prison sentence of about 20 years, U.S. prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Trade War, Facebook, YouTube: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Stranded French Commuters Could Test Macron’s Reform Agenda
item.media:description: Commuters trying to get home on Tuesday evening from the Gare de Lyon railroad station in Paris, on the first day of a rail strike.
item.description: In its second day, a rail strike could threaten the French president’s efforts to end lifelong job security or the rail union’s standing.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
